cells.data:
Lab 7 is out
  • http://clac.cs.columbia.edu/~jae/cs3157/tng/index.html
  • part 1: put things in your home directory, set the permissions correctly so that webserver can retrieve it

  • use firefox

http1.1 — uses the same socket to transfer multiple things
http1.0 — uses a different tcp connection every time a different element is transferred
  • lab 7 uses http1.0 on the server side


last part - can request special url
  • clac.cs.columbia.edu:160000/mdb-lookup
  • this gives you a little interface to get search results from mdb-lookup


                      GET /index html
browser     ——————————————>  http server 
                  <—————————————    
 
                   GET /…/crew.jpg
                  ——————————————>
                  <—————————————— 
                 


                      GET /imdb-lookup?key=ABC                                       ABC
browser     ——————————————>  http server   —————————— > mdb lookup server 
                  <—————————————    (assuming      <—————————— 
                                 search result                  the role of nc)            result
                                                                        formats result line by line till new line character
  • http server doesn’t make a new connection to mdblookupserver
    • there is no new tcp connection
  • the connection between http server is ephemeral. every request could generate a lot of connections. Every time that there is a new search query, there will be a new connection.


  • a web server typically has a backend server giving it some data 
  • SQL - structured query language. language to interact with backend server
  • your browser sends cookies, server looks you up in the lookupserver to get your information.
  • http server = frontend-server. 
    • this is called a 3 tier architecture: browser <-> frontend server <-> backend server
  • in real life you’re not going to modify apache web server. typically, there’s a scripting language to give you power over what the web server does. perl, php, javascript (node.js — allows you to use javascript)
  • LAMP — linux apache mysql php
    • used to be pretty hot
    • node.js is getting very popular because they like java script
  • in modern web:
    • you can put code into the html and send it from the webserver and send the code to the browser, and the browser will do what you specify in the javascript code.
  • json and rest.api are just formats on how information is transferred from browser to http server
